bibl.title: Letter from George P. Berry to William W. Caswell, Jr., November 26, 1952

div1.p: Berry, of Harvard Medical School, explains the background and significance of the upcoming Camp Lazear dedication, and requests that Caswell represent Harvard at the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from George P. Berry to William W. Caswell, Jr., November 26, 1952
div1.opener:
COPY
HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
25 SHATTUCK STREET
BOSTON, MASSACHUSETTS
November 26, 1952
AIR MAIL SPECIAL DELIVERY
Wreath for wood
Mr. William W. Caswell, Jr.
First National Bank of Boston
Havana, Cuba
Dear Mr. Caswell:
div1.p:
You will have to blame Mr. W. H. Claflin for this letter and the favor
which it asks.

On December 3rd, the anniversary of the birthday of Carlos Finlay, which
is “Physicians' Day in Cuba,” the Cuban Government is memorializing the remains
of Walter Reed's Camp Lazear in Quemados de Marianao. The remains of Building
No. 1 have been repaired, a little park has been made and on a stone wall will
be unveiled several individual bronze medallions, one in memory of Dr. Leonard
Wood. Other profiles will be those of Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Carroll, Lazear
and Agramonte. On each side of the medallions will be a bronze tablet with
the names of the volunteers who served as guinea pigs. I understand that
the Cuban Government has invited a number of Americans and American medical
institutions to participate. I understand also that General Streit, Commanding
General of Walter Reed General Hospital, will attend, representing the Surgeon
General, and that others are planning to go. The U. S. Embassy will participate
in the ceremonies.

I believe that this is a significant occasion which will mark the beginning
of a better Cuban-American relationship. As you probably know, Dr. Wood
graduated from the Harvard Medical School in 1884, and for this reason,
plus the fact that it would be a gesture of international medical good-will,
I should very much like to have a graduate of Harvard attend the ceremony and
lay a wreath at the appropriate time and place. Unfortunately we have no
Medical School graduate in Havana. That is why I am writing to ask if you
will be willing to represent Harvard (and the Medical School) at this particular
occasion. I regret that I must necessarily give you such short notice of this
affair. The fact is that the final date for the dedication has only recently
been set.

Dr. Philip S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, who will
attend the ceremony and who has made arrangements with the Cuban authorities
to make a place during the ceremony for the placing of the wreaths, suggests
that a circular wreath of laurel leaves, perhaps 30 inches in diameter, with
a silk ribbon either the collegecolor of the college or red, white and blue for
the United States would be appropriate. Would you be willing to arrange for
the preparation of such a wreath in Havana? Naturally, any costs either for
the wreath or for your personal expenses would be borne by Harvard and I shall
count upon you to inform me.

I am sorry that I cannot give you more specific details as to time, etc.,
at this end. However, Dr. Hench has wired me that if you will contact either
Dr. Rodriguez Exposito or Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana,
they will be able to give you all the information you need. Dr. Hench expects
to be in Havana from Sunday, November 30th, on and can be reached at the Hotel
Nacional.

I realize that I am rather taking it forgranted you will be able to
represent us next Wednesday. It is because time is so short that I have
written in this vein. If for any reason it is not feasible for you to
do so, Dr. Hench will see to it that the wreath is placed at the proper time.

In the hope that you will be able to attend, and with kindest regards,
I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George Packer Berry, M.D.
Dean Signed in Dr. Berry's absence by secretary
CC: Dr. Hench
